Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Situation2: The cleaner is checking the inventory of cleaning supplies during a routine clean.
Story: Tonight is the only evening my girlfriend and I have together before I leave for a week-long work trip. She’s been looking forward to it, planning a cozy dinner and a movie at home. I promised her my full attention, no distractions. But as I’m tidying up the apartment before she arrives, I notice the cleaning supply cabinet is nearly empty—no detergent, barely any sponges, and we’re out of trash bags. As the designated cleaner in our shared space, I’m expected to keep everything stocked and running smoothly. If I don’t restock tonight, the place will be a mess when I get back, and she’ll be frustrated. But if I run out now, I’ll cut into our precious evening together, breaking my promise. I stand in the hallway, keys in one hand, her favorite wine in the other, torn between being the attentive boyfriend she deserves and the responsible cleaner our home needs. My heart pounds as I weigh which expectation to let down.
